title: 111_s1577
content: The Asthma Act may be cited as the ``Asthma Act''. The findings of the Act are outlined in Section 2. Congress finds that asthma affects millions of adults and children in the US, leading to numerous hospital visits and preventable deaths. The annual healthcare costs related to asthma are significant, but with proper management and public health interventions, asthma can be controlled effectively. Population-based research supported by the National Institutes of Health has shown the benefits of combining medical treatment with patient education to improve asthma management. The National Asthma Education and Prevention Program raises awareness about asthma as a chronic disease and promotes effective management through education. Despite extensive knowledge on asthma management strategies, current Federal policy and funding are inadequate, leading to a rise in asthma prevalence, deaths, and expenditures. Additional Federal direction, funding, and support are needed. Additional Federal direction, funding, and support are necessary to increase awareness of asthma as a chronic illness, its symptoms, and environmental factors affecting the disease, as well as to promote education programs for better asthma management. The National Asthma Education and Prevention Program of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute is addressed in Section 3. The National Asthma Education and Prevention Program of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute is authorized additional funding of $4,100,000 annually from 2010 to 2014 to expand the program. A coordinating committee will submit a report to Congress on the scope of the asthma problem in the United States. The coordinating committee will report to Congress on the scope of the asthma problem in the United States and recommend ways to strengthen and coordinate federal asthma-related activities. The Secretary of Education or a designee will be included in the committee's membership. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will focus on asthma-related activities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will collaborate with states to expand public health surveillance activities for asthma, including information and education programs for the public. This includes determining asthma incidence, prevalence, and preventing health consequences through various means like public service announcements. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in collaboration with states, will conduct local asthma surveillance activities to collect data on asthma prevalence, severity, and management quality. This includes telephone surveys and health care facility surveillance. Data on children suffering from asthma and childhood mortality rates associated with asthma will be compiled and published annually. Additional funding of $8,200,000 annually is authorized for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to support asthma surveillance nationally and in each state from 2010 to 2014. SEC. 5. Grants for community outreach on asthma information, education, and services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may grant funds to nonprofit entities for community outreach projects providing asthma information, education, and referrals to health programs. Preference is given to projects in communities identified by grant applicants. The Secretary of Health and Human Services authorizes grants for community projects targeting asthma in underserved areas with low-income residents. Grantees must evaluate project effectiveness, and $4.1 million is allocated annually for this initiative from 2010 to 2014. States are required to develop action plans for asthma and may receive financial incentives for children's health insurance programs. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will carry out a program to encourage states to assist children with asthma according to guidelines. States with satisfactory asthma plans under the Children's Health Insurance Program may receive grants for activities. Matching funds are required for costs. The Secretary may grant funds to states for asthma programs if they provide non-Federal contributions of at least 50% of the costs. Contributions can be in cash or in kind, including services or equipment. The Secretary may grant funds to states for asthma programs if they provide non-Federal contributions of at least 50% of the costs. Contributions can be in cash or in kind, including services or equipment. Federal Government assistance cannot be included in determining non-Federal contributions. The Secretary will publish criteria in the Federal Register for determining satisfactory State plans. Technical assistance will be provided to States in developing provisions for activities under title XXI of the Social Security Act. Funding of $4,100,000 authorized annually for activities under this section from 2010 to 2014. Local educational agencies are required to develop action plans regarding asthma. The Secretary of Education may provide grants to local educational agencies for asthma-related activities at schools in low-income communities. Eligible schools must serve underserved individuals. The curr_chunk discusses grants for collaborative programs between education agencies and public health officials to improve asthma management in schools. Activities include working with healthcare providers, training children and families in asthma self-management, and purchasing equipment. These programs must follow guidelines from the National Institutes of Health and the Environmental Protection Agency. The curr_chunk discusses funding for asthma management in schools, including purchasing equipment, hiring nurses, and training personnel. Definitions for terms like "elementary school" are provided, and $4,100,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2014. Congress encourages hospitals to provide asthma education and training to patients and families upon discharge. They should establish telephone services for patients and communicate with primary health providers. Managed care organizations are urged to disseminate asthma clinical guidelines, collect data, and offer education to patients and families. Congress emphasizes the importance of promoting asthma diagnosis and management guidelines in all federal, state, and local activities. Collaboration with medical, educational, and environmental organizations, as well as advocates for those affected by asthma, is recommended.
